conversation.message: Hello School_C—I'm Student_A. School_C is one of my top choices because I’m looking for a strong academic environment and a community where I can contribute consistently. Could you share what you value most in incoming students and what opportunities (clubs/advanced coursework/support) you emphasize? I’d love to learn more and see how I can be a good fit.

School_C is my second choice and I can still try to build interest without risking an immediate rejection by using [TALK] first. This keeps School_C warm while I observe how competitive School_B looks in early rounds, and positions me to apply quickly to School_C if needed.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_A—thanks for reaching out. At School_C we value students who show consistent academic effort, curiosity, and a willingness to contribute to the community (through clubs, leadership, service, or collaborative projects).

Opportunities you might be interested in include:
- Advanced/accelerated coursework options (with advising to ensure a good fit)
- Academic teams and subject clubs, plus arts and athletics pathways
- Student support structures like teacher office hours, peer tutoring, and counselor check-ins

To better understand your fit and what you’re looking for, could you share:
1) Which academic areas you’re most excited to pursue (and any advanced coursework you’ve taken or want to take), and
2) One or two activities you’d likely join or start at School_C?

Happy to answer any specific questions you have about programs or student life as well.
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority ranks Student_A last. In this round I have an [APPLY] from Student_D, who is ranked above Student_A (B > C > D > E > A). With quota 1, I want to preserve the option to match with a higher-priority student; even if I don’t finalize with D in this specific response, I should not encourage A toward an application that I’m unlikely to accept if higher-priority candidates apply. Since Student_A is only [TALK], I can respond informatively while also probing their commitment/fit and not signaling likely acceptance.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_A,

Thank you for reaching out—happy to share what we value and what tends to help students thrive at School_B.

What we most value in incoming students:
- Consistent academic effort and strong learning habits (steady improvement matters as much as raw scores).
- Curiosity and initiative (students who ask good questions and seek out challenges do especially well).
- Community-mindedness (collaboration, respectful leadership, and contributing to class culture).

Programs/experiences we’re especially proud of:
- Rigorous core academics with opportunities for advanced coursework.
- Student-led clubs and project-based activities where students can take real ownership (academic teams, service/leadership, and interest-based clubs).
- Structured academic support and advising so motivated students can push themselves without getting lost.

What distinguishes students who thrive here:
- They manage their time well and communicate early when they need help.
- They engage beyond the classroom (joining at least one club/team/community role).
- They’re resilient—willing to revise work, learn from feedback, and keep going.

One important note for transparency: our current entering class is full at the moment. That said, if you’re still considering School_B, feel free to share what academic areas and activities you’re most excited about, and I can point you to the best-fit opportunities here and advise you on the best next step.

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_A is contacting with [TALK], not an application, so I should respond with [TALK].
